0: COLUMBUS, Ohio -- The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Is investigating outbreaks of Salmonella in 47 states, including Ohio, connected to backyard flocks. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR As of May 25, 372 people had been infected since Jan. 4. In Ohio, 32 cases were reported to the Ohio Department of Health between Jan. 4 and June 2, said Melanie Amato, public information officer for the department. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ohio topped the list of states that reported illnesses, followed by Kentucky, Tennessee and California. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The outbreaks occurred in Lorain, Ashtabula, Erie and Geauga counties in Northeast Ohio, as well as counties in central and Southeast Ohio, Amato said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There were no reports in Cuyahoga or other Northeast Ohio counties. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The CDC reported that across the nation, 71 illnesses have resulted in hospitalization, and no deaths have been reported. Ill people reported purchasing live baby poultry from feed supply stores, websites, hatcheries and other sources, the CDC said in a statement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Salmonella lives in the intestinal tract of many different animals, and can also be passed from person to person. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The disease is spread by contact with infected chickens, ducks and other poultry. In humans, Salmonella causes diarrhea, fever and abdominal cramps, but doesn't cause symptoms in poultry. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "You feel yucky for a couple of days," Amato said. "Most symptoms go away on their own." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Salmonella tends to flourish in spring and summer as the warm weather allows the disease to flourish. Outbreaks resulting from contact with live poultry have increased in recent years as backyard flocks grow in popularity, the CDC said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The CDC recommends these steps for the safe handling of backyard flocks: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Always wash your hands thoroughly after touching live poultry or anything in their pens. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Don't let chickens or ducks inside the house, on a deck or inside an outdoor kitchen where food is prepared. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Children younger than 5 years, adults older than 65, and people with weakened immune systems should not handle or touch chicks, ducklings, or other live poultry. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Don't hug or kiss chickens and ducks. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Don't take poultry equipment, such as cages or water containers, inside the house for cleaning.
